article.headline: Tesla at $2,000 is new âbull caseâ for Morgan Stanley
article.body: âResilientâ demand for Tesla Inc. vehicles is making the Silicon Valley car maker appear as a less risky company that is on more solid financial footing than other car makers. Thatâs from analyst Adam Jonas of Morgan Stanley, who on Tuesday upped his price target on TSLA, +1.89% Â shares to $740, implying a downside of around 47% from Tuesdayâs share price. Jonas also set a âbull case scenarioâ stock price of $2,070, an upside of around 48%. According to FactSet, which surveyed 32 Tesla analysts, the average price target on the stock is $778, with a handful of outliers setting price targets above $1,000. Recently, analyst Dan Ives of Wedbush also set a âbull case scenarioâ for Tesla shares at $2,000 alongside his price target of $1,250. Teslaâs second-quarter production and delivery numbers were âsignificantly aheadâ of Morgan Stanleyâs expectations in a three-month period that was shaping up to be âextremely difficult,â Jonas said. Donât miss:Tesla stock rockets higher as quarterly sales crush expectations âTesla has demonstrated one very powerful differentiating quality vs. many of its auto peers: demand is holding up better,â Jonas said in his note. Tesla may see some cash burn from its working capital but it is âin position to post an above break-even U.S. GAAP result in (the second quarter).â Some long-term concerns remain, chiefly around profits in China, âpoorâ fundamentals for the auto industry in general, and the âinevitableâ competition in EV and in autonomous vehicles from well-heeled companies such as Amazon.com Inc. AMZN, +3.01%, Apple Inc. AAPL, +1.74%, Alphabet Inc. GOOG, +1.97% Â and others, Jonas said. Tesla shares have been on a tear in recent sessions, boosted by the quarterly sales data, and on Tuesday were poised for a fifth straight record close. The stock has gained 235% this year, contrasting with losses of 2% and 8% for the S&P 500 index SPX, +0.87% Â and the Dow Jones Industrial Average. DJIA, +0.56% Â
